description: The GNU Software Project describes Emacs as "An extensible, customizable, free/libre text editor — and more" ... and GNU Emacs certainly is "more." Because Emacs is written in C and its own dialect of Lisp, Emacs Lisp (ELisp), it is adaptable to handle virtually any type of text from typesetting TeX to being a "project planner, mail and news reader, debugger interface, calendar, and more." It shines as a programming environment, from being a simple editor to use with a compiler, to being an expandable IDE. Getting proficient at using GNU Emacs -- a process I candidly admit I'm still navigating after several years -- takes an investment of effort and time, and the only way to learn if Emacs fits your proferred methods of using such an exteensible tool is to invest the effort and time in learning it and experimenting. Also, I see the whole Vi versus Emacs rivalry as silly: Knowing the basics of each tool is essential for any professional and Emacs, for instance, which I would be remiss about if I did not mention is excellent package manager, has packages that allow Vi users to feel right at home.
summary: More Than a Text Editor, and Worth Learning

description: As a whole life challenge

emacs is one of the best flagships of free software, saying it's not free is like saying the sky is not blue. lol

During graduate school I lived in Emacs. I used AucTeX for writing presentations and docments, wl for email, term for my command line, org mode for my agenda, and dired to move my files. Whenever I try to use a new program, I always end up going back to Emacs because of the customization and the keyboard commands. Also, it just works (and on multiple operating systems too)!

emacs is so much more than an editor, but it's also great as an editor. Once you get used to the way of thinking, and some quirky keyboard shortcuts, you will never look back. Check out org-mode if you are into taking notes or organizing and documenting stuff.
Emacs is awesome once you put in the effort to get familiar with it.
Emacs is the only app you need to get things don! In the beginning, the learning process was a bit slow. But, when you get hang of Emacs, it simply shines!

Seriously though, you don't need to be an elite hacker to use Emacs.

Emacs is famously extensible but, other than Prot's highly accessible Modus themes, I generally stick with the defaults and built-in tools.

Don't be afraid; just have fun!
summary: Configured to brew my coffee and do the shopping, would recommend

You're probably already familiar with what Emacs is and what it can do, so allow me to, so allow me to present the core philosophy of the program; be introspectable and be extensible.

What this means is that everything you do in Emacs, every keybinding, every button action is bound to a function, which you can then read the source code of, modify and re-evaluate.

For programmers, this is nirvana. Non-programmers also benefit in the form of excellent extensions that are written for Emacs that are easily install-able via the built-in package manager.
summary: One of the best software packages ever written

description: I use emacs for a long time now, it became a great tool (lots of packages) for my development and notes workflow. If you have time to spend for learning emacs, give it a try.

If I could choose one program to bring with me to a desserted island, it would be Emacs. There is nothing you can't do here.

The learning curve for brand new users are way smaller than for something like VIM, but it's more complicated than VSCode. Frameworks like Doom Emacs however brings the complexity down to the same level of VSCode.

If you want an editor that works regardless of language or workflow, this is for you. If you want a platform/program/operatingsystem where everything is as integrated as Mac OS, this editor is for you.
summary: simply the single greatest program of all time
